etymologies: Old English slæc ‘inclined to be lazy, unhurried’, of Germanic origin; related to Latin laxus ‘loose’

definitions: not taut or held tightly in position; loose
shortDefinitions: not taut or held tightly in position

definitions: (of business) characterized by a lack of work or activity; quiet
shortDefinitions: (of business or trade) characterized by lack of work or activity

examples.text: they were working at a slack pace

definitions: having or showing laziness or negligence
shortDefinitions: having or showing laziness or negligence

definitions: (of a tide) neither ebbing nor flowing

examples.text: soon the water will become slack, and the tide will turn

definitions: the part of a rope or line which is not held taut; the loose or unused part

examples.text: I picked up the rod and wound in the slack

shortDefinitions: part of rope or line which is not held taut

definitions: a spell of inactivity or laziness

examples.text: he slept deeply, refreshed by a little slack in the daily routine
he put on a gray shirt and loose cotton slacks
slacking the outhaul allows you to adjust the sail

definitions: decrease or reduce in intensity, quantity, or speed

examples.text: the flow of blood slacked off

shortDefinitions: decrease or reduce in intensity or speed

examples.text: she reprimanded her girls if they were slacking
150 sacks of lime were slacked by the inrushing water
their heads were hanging slack in attitudes of despair

etymologies: late Middle English: probably from Low German or Dutch

definitions: coal dust or small pieces of coal

examples.text: the fire was stoked with a mixture of slack and cement

shortDefinitions: coal dust or small pieces of coal
